title: Opening Bell: Caution Prevails Ahead Of Fed Decision; Oil Spike Eases
text:
U.S. futures slide on investor caution ahead of Fed announcement

Oil prices ease as Saudi Arabia reassures markets over supply capacity

Yields slide for third straight day on rate cut expectations

Key Events

Futures on the , and traded in a holding pattern below neutral levels this morning, marking time ahead of an expected U.S. . In the background, lingering concerns about U.S.-China trade tensions—with working-level negotiators set to resume talks ahead of higher-level meetings in October—contributed to investor caution.

Europe's rebounded from a drop, with gains in telecom stocks offsetting declines in household goods and financial shares—the latter being weighed down by an increased outlook for lower interest rates.

Earlier, in the Asian session, regional indices ended mixed, with South Korea’s (+0.41%) outperforming and China’s (+0.25%) ranking second. Australia’s (-0.2%) led the session’s losses.

Meanwhile, oil prices extended Tuesday's steep slide that , after Saudi Arabia moved to reassure markets over supply recovery.

Global Financial Affairs

On Tuesday, the gained 0.26%, weighed down by stocks (-1.47%) before Saudi Arabia’s Energy Minister Prince Abdulaziz bin Salman the country was repairing its oil facilities and would restore full output capacity by the end of the month. shares fared as the session’s outperformers (+1.39%).

UST 10-Year Daily Chart

Meanwhile, the yield on Treasurys tumbled for the third straight day, as investor appetite for government bonds surged ahead of . Technically, the three-day drop followed the test of the 100 DMA’s resistance below the downtrend line since November.

USD/JPY Daily Chart

The dollar gained against the but remained below yesterday’s highs of a shooting star’s resistance. It still hovered above the 100 DMA and the top of a falling channel, demonstrating how crucial the next move could be for the ongoing trend.

WTI Daily Chart

slightly extended yesterday’s 5.66% plunge but remained above yesterday’s lows, suggesting support.

Technically, the wild swings of the initial —seen on both the U.S. benchmark and the global benchmark, —may solidify into a stable short-term uptrend after establishing an ascending series of peaks and troughs.

Up Ahead

The Federal Reserve is widely expected to lower U.S. interest rates in response to slowing global economic growth and muted inflation. Chairman Jerome Powell will hold a post-decision on Wednesday.

The Bank of Japan is on Thursday, followed by a briefing from Governor Haruhiko Kuroda.

and also decide policy on Thursday.

Australia are out on Thursday.

Quarterly expiration of futures and options on indexes and stocks on Friday could add to this week's key calendar events to boost volatility.

Market Moves

Stocks

Spain’s increased 0.2%.

The gained 0.3%.

Currencies

The climbed 0.13 out a 0.6% hole%.

The declined 0.2% to $1.2469.

The dropped 0.1% to $1.1059.

The Japanese yen weakened 0.1% to 108.19 per dollar.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasurys slipped two basis points to 1.78%.

The yield on Treasurys fell two basis points to 1.71%.

Britain’s yield dropped two basis points to 0.673%.

Japan’s yield declined three basis points to -0.185%.

Commodities

West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.2% to $59.25 a barrel.

held steady at $1,501.93 an ounce.

increased 0.3% to $93.45 per metric ton.
